I think probably more important is whether it is more important to be persuasive or to be right? Is it important to be persuasive at all?
 
 I guess it depends on what you want out of a debate. If you want to know what is right (what is the [more likely] right thing to do in a prescriptive debate; what is [more likely] true in a descriptive debate), then there is really no sense in being persuasive; is there? There is no necessary correlation between correctness and persuasiveness. For example, sales people very often are pretty convincing, and, as so often known, some of them aren't at all truthful. Would it be wise, then, to lie in a debate so long as the other person doesn't find out?
 
 So I guess I don't see a point in trying to be persuasive in a debate as much as to be right. Certainly there are arguments as to exactly what is right. I think that everyone would accept that ontological correctness or correctness by deductive logic is considered the only absolute "rightness". There are certain facts that can be seen as right, while not provable in a deductive sense -- say epistemological facts. For example, "if I release a rock in mid air, it will fall" is probably considered true while it's not ontologically true as nothing guarantees that. What people use more often is inductive or probabilistic infererence (I guess you can just as well say that epistemological facts are just highly probable inductive inferences) -- as an aside, most people who use this type or argument is wrong [even this statement in itselve is probably wrong]. The more objective view at probabilistic inference is of course to group all of your known premises into a set of events E and to calculate P(C|E) for C your conclusion. If P(C|E) is within epsilon of 1, then your conclusion is acceptable -- people don't do this at all, and so you get statements such as "some MACs perform better than some PCs, so MACs perform better than PCs" (while "perform" here is ambiguous, the statement still illustates the fallacy), which is clearly flawed.
 
 Okay, so let's summarize my digression before moving on:
 1. being persuasive is not important in a debate
 2. being right is important in a debate, and the followings are ways to be right:
 2a. deduction (there many subclasses of this) give absolute correctness
 2b. application of epistemological facts
 2c. probabilistic inference
 
 
 With all of that aside, how to be persuasive? Persuasion is really a psychological problem. I certainly don't know anything astounding about the subject, but many obvious things seem to work. The best thing to do seems to be to find out about the person and assume his/her superiority, and, most of all, appealing to the other person. For example, if you are arguing against a mother on how bad the war in Iraq is, maybe bringing up parents of dead soldiers would help. Again, it really depends, obviously, on the other person, so it's hard to say whether there is a set of "work for all" rules to be persuasive.
 
 And finally, NEVER EVER, in a debate, make a proposition without backing arguments.

You don't need to know anything about the topic to be persuasive in a debate. It helps, but it's not essential. 
 
 Figure out exactly what you're trying to get the other person to accept as true, figure out how you need to go from their starting point to reach that conclusion, fill in the gaps with logical arguments and then back up the arguments with facts or (preferably) case studies. 
 
 But the ultimate trick is knowing what you're trying to prove and what the other person is trying to prove and identifying what arguments you need to make to ensure that you have a better case. 
 
 Also, one of the best ways to change someones mind is to start by accepting all their premises and still proving that your conclusion stands, so, for example, in an abortion debate when you're proposing (for) abortion: EVEN IF you accept that life begins at conception, still being able to argue that women should be able to choose abortion. It's really effective. :) 
 *unfortunately, often the only way to do it is to deliberately twist what the other side has said to suit your case, which isn't a particularly good tactic*

After posting for a short time there are some things I note in order to be persuasive:
 
 1) Do not malign another's position. You may disagree with it (vehemently) but using charged words will result in less debate and a lot of clogging on the servers.
 
 2) Give people points on things not crucial to the discussion. This will allow you to focus on the "real" arguments and make you look reasonable.
 
 3) Be ready to apologize when you screw up. Everyone does. Refusal to admit it only shows your own problems.
 
 4) STICK TO THE TOPIC. Moving around on other things (gun debates in the abortion forum for instance, hypothetically) only confuses things and adds fuel to the fire against your arguments
 
 5) Use traps and tricks sparingly. There is no substitute for good logic. A trap or trick is needed at times but the less used the better it will look.
 
 6) If you state an opinion, identify it as such. If it has a basis present the facts and not other opinions
 
 7) Know your logical fallacies and name them.

 Regarding convincing the opposition, there are some debaters who are trying to debate honestly and would be able to be convinced, given calm, rational and respectful arguement. Others might take more effort and patience and still others will never be convinced since they came into the debate with set minds. I think that it is still worth the effort to at least try to convince most debate opponents. 
 
 As long as one stays rational, gives supporting evidence, and, importantly, stays respectful in tone, then one at least has a chance. Far too often, I see people debate here on these forums and quickly loose patience with an opponent who may not be rational or open-minded. As soon as one looses patience with one's opponent and becomes insulting, then the chance of convincing that opponent dwindles significantly. Human nature seems to be such that, even if someone knows they are wrong, they will never admit it to those who attack them with disrespect. I think it is very important to let the opponent save face and to show that you at least are trying to understand their arguements. Also, if you approach the opponent respectfully and seriously try to understand their position, then there is always the chance that there is something valuable in their position that you might not have considered, which could then even change your own position.
 
 As for convincing an audience, I still think that arguing from a calm, rational and respectful point of view is best. One doesn't need to convince those people who already share your point of view. It is the near-opposition or those on the fence that one tries to convince and they will become closed minded if one insults their view. Again, as with ones opponents, if one wants to convince an audience, one cannot disparage their views. 
 
 That being said, there are some posters (Supersport comes to mind from the Evolution vs Creationism forum) whose main weapon seems to be insult and whose arguements are too often irrational. Though this may do nothing to convince the near-opposition or to convince those who have some understanding of the subject matter, insult may make one appear strong and winning to those who do not understand the detailed arguements anyway. I think it is just best to ignore such posters until they go away. I spent far too much time arguing with such a beligerently irrational poster and regret all the effort that I wasted on that poster.

 In the real world, though, particularly in politics, such irrational arguments have to be faced or else the opposition wins votes and their agenda is the one that gets implemented. I really don't have a good feel for how the Democrats can battle the absurd propaganda and unfounded accusations of the Republicans in a way that can convince the large group of voters who make decisions based more on gut reaction than on rationality. Certainly, the intellectual approach of a Kerry or Gore not only doesn't win those votes but alienates the large swath of people who seem to think of intellectuals as elitist snobs. That is why Clinton, who was far more intelligent than recent presidents, was also able to show a down-home charm that drew a lot of support to him (though it's too bad that he had to be so stupid about his sexual escapades - too much of an attempt to emulate Kennedy if you ask me). Anyway, I think the Democrats have to learn to take on a down-home language and charm that can convince a larger constituency.

Here's the technique that I used and it seems to be working or so I believe:
 
 1. Be prepare - know what you and also your opponents are going to argue about. Avoid being stump by their attacks.
 
 2. Catch phases - (i.e. Executing a murderer is directly proportionate to robbing a robber or raping a rapist) only 1 thing to say, they stick to your mind and most importantly the judges.
 
 3. Speak loud and clear in a proper manner. Show no sign of anger or panic. If you can accomplish this you may have achieved 2 things: a) Make your opposition angry b) Show your confidence and draw the judges attention to you.
 
 4. Formality - this always help when you're trying to make a point. It gives your statements a stronger authority.
 
 5. Factual evidence - these are always good. It's even better if you have the actual evidence or statistic to display to the panel of judges. Arguments are always more believable with some kind of back ups.
 
 6. Dress up!! - Researchs showed that a person who dressed nicely created a better impression and cause the judges to think that he take the argument seriously.
